revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |width=264px |title=Dance Dance Revolution
Hottest Party |image=Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party all cover art.png |caption=Japanese (left), North American (middle) and PAL (right) cover art versions |developer=[[Konami]] |publisher=Konami |series=''[[Dance Dance Revolution]]'' |engine=Hottest Party |released={{vgrelease|NA|September 25, 2007 {{Cite web |url=http://www.konami.com/Konami/ctl3810/cp20107/si2452890/cl1/dance_dance_revolution_hottest_party_with_dance_pad |title=Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party with Dance Pad |accessdate=2008-03-24 |publisher=Konami |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5WhHdtwUG?url=http://www.konami.com/Konami/ctl3810/cp20107/si2452890/cl1/dance_dance_revolution_hottest_party_with_dance_pad |archivedate=2008-03-30 |url-status=dead }}|JP|October 24, 2007|NA|November 6, 2007 (Game only)|EU|March 28, 2008|NZL|April 11, 2008|AUS|April 18, 2008{{Cite web |url=http://games.nintendo.com.au/title.php?id=1621 |title=Dancing Stage: Hottest Party |accessdate=2008-03-29 |work=Nintendo Australia |publisher=Nintendo |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080521234630/http://games.nintendo.com.au/title.php?id=1621 |archivedate=2008-05-21 |url-status=dead }}}} |genre=[[Music video game|Music]], [[exergaming|exercise]] |modes=[[Single-player]], [[multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms=[[Wii]] }} {{nihongo|'''''Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party'''''|ダンスダンスレボリューションホッテストパーティー|Dansu Dansu Reboryūshon Hottesuto Pātī}}, known as '''''Dancing Stage Hottest Party''''' in the European and Oceanic regions, is a [[video game]] released by Konami in 2007 and 2008 to several countries for the [[Wii]] console. Konami took the game beyond the traditional setup of ''[[Dance Dance Revolution]]'' by incorporating the [[Wii Remote]] and the standard [[dance pad]] into a full body motion game. It has two sequels, ''[[Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party 2]]'' and ''[[Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party 3]]''. Unlike the previous release of ''Dance Dance Revolution'' on a [[Nintendo]] console, ''[[Dance Dance Revolution Mario Mix]]'', ''Hottest Party'' was not a collaboration between Konami and Nintendo. It is not a sequel, but the [[GameCube]] accessories for ''Mario Mix'' are compatible with ''Hottest Party''.{{Cite web |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/760/760878p1.html |title=Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party Hands-on |accessdate=2007-02-11 |first=Mark |last=Bozen |date=2007-02-02 |publisher=IGN |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5WhW4FHko?url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/760/760878p1.html |archivedate=2008-03-30 |url-status=dead }} ==Gameplay== {{See also|Gameplay of Dance Dance Revolution}} The Gameplay is largely unchanged from other ''Dance Dance Revolution'' games.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/dance-dance-revolution-hottest-party-review/1900-6180941/ |title=Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party Review |accessdate=June 8, 2019 |first=Joe|last=Dodson|date=October 12, 2007 |publisher=[[Gamespot]]}} However, the game features additional modes taking advantage of the hardware of the Wii. The game allows the integration of the [[Wii Remote]] into gameplay, where steps can be replaced by markers requiring a hand motion with the remote.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamesradar.com/dance-dance-revolution-hottest-party-review/ |title=If this is the hottest party you know of, you may need some new friends |accessdate=June 8, 2019 |first=Andrew|last=Hayward|date=October 8, 2007 |publisher=[[GamesRadar+]]}} Other step types include steps which must be hit twice. ''Hottest Party'' includes a single player mode (Groove Circuit and free play), and Workout Mode.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2008/01/28/dance-dance-revolution-hottest-party-review |title=DANCE DANCE REVOLUTION: HOTTEST PARTY REVIEW |accessdate=June 8, 2019|date=January 28, 2008 |publisher=[[IGN]]}} Free play gives the players a free choice of songs, which can be played in Sync mode (several players play the same chart, and only the lowest step judgment on each arrow will count), and Friendship mode (where the highest step judgment is counted).{{Cite web|url=https://www.post-gazette.com/business/tech-news/2007/11/08/Game-Daze-Dance-Dance-Revolution-Hottest-Party/stories/200711080353 |title=Game Daze: 'Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party' |accessdate=June 8, 2019|date=November 8, 2007 |publisher=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]}} In Groove Circuit, players will play through venues and different groups of songs. At the end of each venue, a boss battle will start.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411031445/http://wii.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r31750.htm |title=Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party Review |accessdate=June 8, 2019|date=September 25, 2007 |publisher=GameZone}} There are challenges for each dance, as well. The game supports multiplayer which requires four dance mats for each player.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/review/14673/dance-dance-revolution-hottest-party-wii |title=Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party|accessdate=June 8, 2019|date=October 25, 2007 |publisher=Nintendo World Report}} [[Image:Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party gameplay 1.jpg|thumb|right|In Friendship Mode, the highest step judgement is counted for all players]] ==Music== The soundtrack of ''Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party'' differs in the Japanese release. "B4U (The Acolyte Mix)", "Gonna Make You Sweat (Everybody Dance Now)", "Rhythm is a Dancer" and "Unappreciated" are only featured in the North American/European/Oceanic release. "B4U (Rising Sun Mix)", "Double Tornard", "Pluto the First" and "True♥Love (Clubstar's True Club Mix)" are included in their place. All of the Japanese exclusives except "B4U (Rising Sun Mix)" were made available in later DDR console releases, such as ''Hottest Party 3'' and ''[[Dance Dance Revolution (2010 video game)|DDR 2010]]''. "Lessons by DJ" in the Japanese release has Japanese language voice overs during the song, whereas all other releases have English voice overs. {|class="wikitable" |- |+{{nowrap|Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party'' soundtrack (Japan)}}{{Cite web |url=http://zenius-i-vanisher.com/v4/ddrgamedb.php?gameid=50 |title=DanceDanceRevolution HOTTEST PARTY (Japan) Song List |accessdate=2008-03-22 Many reviews agree the hand motions freshen the DDR experience and are a positive addition to the game.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gameshark.com/reviews/2769/p_10/Dance-Dance-Revolution-Hottest-Party-Review.htm |title=Hottest Party is the best DDR game yet. |accessdate=2007-10-28 |first=Dan |last=Clarke |date=2007-10-05 |publisher=GameShark |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5WhewRArh?url=http://www.gameshark.com/reviews/2769/p_10/Dance-Dance-Revolution-Hottest-Party-Review.htm |archivedate=2008-03-30 |url-status=dead }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.konami.jp/bemani/ddr/na/gs/hp/ Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party teaser site] *[http://www.konami.jp/bemani/ddr/jp/gs/hp/index.html Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party official site] {{in lang|ja}} *[http://www.ddronlinecommunity.com/ Dance Dance Revolution Online Community] {{S-start}} {{Succession box|before=nothing|title=''Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party''|years=2007|after={{Nowrap|''[[Dance Dance Revolution Hottest Party 2]]''}}}} {{End}} {{DanceDanceRevolution}} [[Category:2007 video games]] [[Category:Dance Dance Revolution games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Germany]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Wii-only games]] [[Category:Wii games]]
